texts.shortText:
Colony upright and bushy with flat branches that bifurcate regularly and are usually arranged in a distinct spiral pattern. Colour light yellow to orange, with zooids showing up as dark spots within the zooecia.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia are less than 1 mm long, elongate-rectangular and arranged usually 3 abreast (2 at tips). Each individual has a very large, oval opening about 70% of total length and four tiny short stubby teeth near the orifice. Some lateral zooecia have a single minute avicularium on the outer distal corner and another frontal one at the basal end. Others have a pair of tiny frontal avicularia. (The long, curved distal spines present in several related species are absent).
Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 4 cm tall.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Lambertâ€™s Bay to East London.
Found on rocky substrata, especially in shaded areas, often among sponges and other bryozoans. Depth range intertidal to 100 m. Fed on by the Cape silvertip nudibranch Antiopella capensis.

All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
The colony is hermaphrodite, but individual zooids male or female. Colonies expand by budding new zooecia at the tips. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction.

The spiral branching pattern is fairly diagnostic, but there are a number of other common species that form similar yellow to orange branching bushes. Microscopic examination of the zooecia is needed to distinguish these with certainty. The Curled bush bryozoan Menipea crispa has incurving branches and the Bonsai bush bryozoan Bicellariella bonsai drooping ones (like a bonsai willow bush), but both species have long, curved spines extending from the distal tips of each zooecium. The Fan-shaped bryozoan Bugulina flabellata lack these spines, but has 3-5 rows of zooecia along each branch and bears prominent rounded reproductive bodies (ovicells).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 138).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 128).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 21).
